text:
My Eight years old nephew just asked me; You, do you like this Nigeria like this?

I said, Yes and asked him same question.

He said, No. His complaint is simply that there is no steady power supply.

text:

text: The same school that taught impulse giving especially towards all projects that has to do with the school, as a sure way to financial success, is the same school teaching financial prudence. #Liveyourtruth

author: The Ace MC
text:
You can see the things guiding our lives as Nigerians oo. 
Why should there not be light in the first place? 🤣🤣 
The way our inefficiencies as a country has permeated every sphere of our lives. They are so pronounced even in our love and affection stories.  😂

author: The Ace MC
text: In Nigeria, 'Have you eaten?' during courtship graduates to 'Is there light?' during marriage.😁

author: The Ace MC
text: By the way, 'danfo' is what we call our yellow and black commercial buses in Lagos, could be 17 passengers, 13 passengers, etc. The longer and wider version called 'molue'.

author: The Ace MC
text:
When goals align, unity is almost automatic.
This is a good theory.
Who are you following? Who is following you? Are yours goals aligned? Are our goals aligned as a nation?
If no, then more than half of our budget should just be for conflict resolution.

author: The Ace MC
text: Have you wondered how passengers in a danfo can be fighting in a minute and in another minute unanimously attack/appease any third party (a reckless driver/police) threatening their safe and timely arrival at destination?

author: The Ace MC
text:

author: The Ace MC
text:
Religion and ethnicity should actually liberate and not gag, the fact that we have plethora of them should actually present us with multiple choices to reaching one goal rather than restricting us to a
one-or-doom way of reach same goal. 

Are you free?

2/2

text:

text:

We will still need our older ones.

author: The Ace MC
text: The way the narrative changed from Drivers' License to seat belt is still strange to me. It's a Sunday evening and i only left my house to get fuel. My friend and i were both on seat belt. I'm at the Kuje office standing, they have refused to hand me my license. Please help @frsc

author: The Ace MC
text: He has since held on to it. I'm at their Kuje Office presently and he has changed the story from Drivers' License to Seat Belt. He claims my friend on the passenger seat was not on his belt; a claim that is totally false. @FRSCNigeria

author: The Ace MC
text:
If only i knew, while enroute Abuja from Lagos, i would have counted the number of checkpoints i met between Okenne and Abuja.

Not to exaggerate, checkpoints would be up to 30.

My experience with these men manning these checkpoints is another story on its own.

author: The Ace MC
text:
How i managed to pass some courses in school amazes me when i reminisce about their exams.

I still remember concluding my Critical Writing exam with '...so many points but for time' because i was just tired of writing.

author: The Ace MC
text:
If your definition of Monday mornings is the kind in Lagos, that's a generalisation so unbalanced.

Lagos will make you dread and detest Monday mornings.

author: The Ace MC
text:
Even eating in such moments was considered insensitive.

But today, a whole community could be facing maiming and wipeout  and some dude would be trending for kissing some chick.

Talk about value for life.

9. (End).

author: The Ace MC
text:
I still remember how the reception of death news felt like, while growing up.

The silence, tension and morosity could be so loud such that, even as a kid, you knew better than to interrupt that moment with any mundane request. 

8.

author: The Ace MC
text:
Addressing these killings is even more difficult for the government, but they would rather we pray for Beirut.

Who do us like this?

7.

author: The Ace MC
text:
Killings occur almost on a daily basis in Southern Kaduna here in Nigeria and protecting the lives of Nigerian citizens has become an insurmountable challenge for the Nigerian government.

6.

author: The Ace MC
text:
Death news have become so normal that leaders in government now select which ones to react to, with their everyday response which has now become a mantra: The perpetrators shall be brought to justice.

5.

author: The Ace MC
text:
Perhaps, i should have just known that such trucks would be plying my route and not go out.

Value for life has hit the lowest possible level on the diminishing curve such that one hears a person or a number of persons die and one does not even flinch.

4.

author: The Ace MC
text:
...crushed by a container loosely placed on a truck by bunch of lunatics whose lunacy takes root in the irresponsibility of the government whose task it is to secure my life and properties.

3.

author: The Ace MC
text:
Every car/truck one drives/walks past or drives past one, irrespective of one's location at that moment is a potential death.

Perhaps someone can tell me when going out, to seek my daily bread, how to be careful out there in my car or in a public vehicle, so i don't get... 

2.

author: The Ace MC
text:
The chance of a safe return to base keeps getting slimmer everyday with numerous but avoidable death traps littering every nook and cranny of my country.

Yes, i know living life itself is risky, but living in Nigeria, my country, is riskier.

1.
